item.title: Breaking bread
item.description: I watched a TV show as a kid that featured a monk happily making bread, folding and kneading away in his black robe, and I’ve been on a quest to make good bread myself ever since. That quest involved a lot of reading and failed attempts at home before I finally sought the help of professionals. With a lot of classes I’ve tried, I managed to make an OK loaf on the day, but then failed when trying to follow the whole process at home.

item.title: Pasticcini di mandorle
item.description: I like to make notes in my cookbooks to remind myself of what went right and wrong with the recipe. Lower heat next time. Don’t forget the baking powder! Even better the day after. After I’ve made a recipe a number of times or generally feel I’ve got the hang of it, I just put a tick beside the title. My pages of Rachel Roddy’s Five Quarters: Recipes and Notes from A Kitchen in Rome are full of tick marks and pasticcini di mandorle — soft almond biscuits — has six of them.
